So if the given is series, the formula that we'll use is Ct = 1/C1 + 2/ C2... + 1 / Cn.   If the given is parallel, the formula that we'll use is Ct = C1 + C2...Cn. capacitors in parallel act like resistors in series. So their rules are kinda reversed

divide the given equation by C2 after dividing the given equation we get:Q2/C2=Q(total)/C1+C2 which implies V2=V(total) and this statement is only valid for parallel series of capacitors cause voltage always remains constant.Hope this makes sense :)
you can try looking at voltage and current dividers for resistors. (current in parallel and voltage in series, but series capacitors act like resistors in parallel and vice-versa)

Capacitor 1 takes 30,000 micro Coulombs because when the capacitors are simplified into a single capacitor, the equivalent capacitance is 75 micro Farads. Use that value with the voltage of 400 volts in the equation C=Q/V in order to get 30,000 micro Coulombs. Since charge is constant in series, and capacitor 1 is in series, it must also have a charge of 30,000 micro Coulombs.
